Award.AwardTitle: Phosphotyrosine-dependent regulatory mechanisms of mammalian brain development: A large-scale phosphoproteomic and biochemical study.
Award.AbstractNarration: This PI seeks to understand how neurons of the developing mammalian brain are appropriately positioned in the brain. During brain development many neurons migrate from their places of birth and are guided by cues in their environment to make the critical connections and structures of a functioning brain. This study will use biochemical, cell biological and newly developed proteomic approaches to study proteins that are known to be essential for neuronal positioning, but whose regulation is poorly understood. A major focus of the study will be the characterization of novel tyrosine phosphorylation events recently identified by Ballif on these neuronal-positioning proteins from mouse brain. Tyrosine phosphorylation is one of the most dynamic mechanisms reversibly regulating proteins and altering cell fate. It is anticipated that this study will make clear the role of targeted tyrosine phosphorylation events on critical proteins governing brain development. Additionally, this study will identify and quantify across development many thousands of tyrosine phosphorylation events on hundreds of brain proteins, accomplishing in a few years what would have required decades using traditional methods. To accelerate the research of other developmental neurobiolists in the field, all identified phosphorylation events will be submitted to public databases including Phosphosite (http://www.phosphosite.org). On the heels of the genomic revolution today's undergraduate and graduate students need access to training in proteomic technology. In collaboration with established infrastructure and outreach programs in Vermont, Dr. Ballif will teach a proteomic module to over 150 undergraduates at nine institutions of higher learning in Vermont; will mentor in research projects two full time graduate students and more than ten undergraduate summer students (including minorities); and will train the proteomics staff in large-scale quantitative proteomics making this technology available to the many investigators it serves each year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The development of the mammalian brain is a highly-orchestrated and complex process involving a host of different cell types acting in concert. In order for brain tissue to form properly, embryonic brain cells send chemical instructions to each other. These instructional cues trigger cascades of molecular events in the responding cells, telling them how to move, how to make connections with other cells, to proliferate and/or change their shape and function. While understanding these processes is essential to know how brains develop, measuring only one event in one process has traditionally been laborious. Recent technological advances in protein mass spectrometry have made it possible to capture and measure, on a large-scale, the critical molecular events following cellular responses to developmental cues. We have used these technologies and have monitored thousands of these events at different stages of development of the mouse brain. Our results provide scientists a reference atlas for these events across this model of mammalian brain development. We have also characterized in detail the functional relevance of several of these individual events. Collectively these results have been published in six peer-reviewed journal articles and one book chapter. Furthermore, we have one article under review for publication and three additional manuscripts in preparation. Additional publications include all or part of four Ph.D. dissertations, one M.S. thesis and four undergraduate honors theses.

Broader impacts: In addition to training a few hundred undergraduates during outreach laboratory modules and lectures at the University of Vermont and at Vermont baccalaureate colleges (Norwich University, St. Michael’s College, Green Mountain College, Johnson State College, Castleton State College, Lyndon State College, Marlboro College and Middlebury College), 34 trainees have been directly mentored in the lab while completing the research aims of the project. These trainees include one visiting scholar, five graduate students, 23 undergraduates and five high school seniors (from Puerto Rico).  Seven (~21%) of the 34 trainees were from minority backgrounds and 24 (~70%) were women. These trainees have importantly advanced in their careers. The visiting scholar is now an associate dean and the two Ph.D. students that graduated took postdoctoral positions. Of the undergraduates that have graduated five are in Ph.D. programs, eight served as laboratory technicians, one is in the Army Medical Service Corps, one is an emergency medical technician instructor, and one completed a M.S. degree and was a Fulbright Scholar in Wales. Several of the others are currently applying for Ph.D. or M.D. programs. All five of the high school seniors are enrolled in college. Importantly, several student trainees were co-authors on the published and submitted manuscripts including the visiting scholar, 5 graduate students, 13 undergraduates, and 2 high school seniors. Additional students will be co-authors in the three manuscripts in preparation. Finally, as part of the intellectual infrastructure-development goals of this award, the Vermont Genetics Network proteomics staff at the University of Vermont were trained in conducting large-scale protein mass spectrometry methodologies and now offer this to their many clients both regionally, nationally and internationally.
